Description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN THE MAPUTO PROVINCE BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND PROMOTING HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE. LOCATED WITHIN THE GREATER LIMPOPO TRANSFRONTIER CONSERVATION AREA  TFCA  SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS LANDSCAPE IS HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 47,405 ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT  HEC , HABITAT LOSS, AND POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE   1  DEPLOYING ELEPHANT GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM  GPS  COLLARS AND ANALYZING THEIR MOVEMENTS TO SUPPORT CORRIDOR PLANNING AND DESIGN   2  IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL HEC HOTSPOTS WITHIN CORRIDOR ZONES AND ALIGNING ELEPHANT MOVEMENTS WITH HEC RAPID RESPONSE UNITS   3  FACILITATING INFORMATION SHARING WITH COMMUNITIES AND CO-PRODUCTION OF HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE TOOLKITS   4  CONDUCTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMMING AND SKILLS TRAINING WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS, WITH AN ADDED FOCUS ON WOMEN  AND  5  CONDUCTING CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS THAT PROMOTE PRO-ELEPHANT INCOME-GENERATING OPPORTUNITIES, INCLUDING BEEHIVE AND CHILI FENCES, UNPALATABLE PERMACULTURE GARDENS, CRAFT SALES, AND TREE PLANTING AND PROTECTION.

SUPPORT FOR COMMUNITY-INCLUSIVE CONSERVATION OF AFRICAN ELEPHANT IN THE NORTH LUANGWA ECOSYSTEM, ZAMBIA":THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN NORTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK (NLNP) BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND BUILDING A CONSTITUENCY FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION. AS PART OF THE LUANGWA-ZAMBEZI VALLEY SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO ZAMBIA'S LARGEST AND MOST STABLE POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS (APPROXIMATELY 14,000 INDIVIDUALS) AND ITS ONLY BLACK RHINO POPULATION. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HABITAT LOSS, HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC), AND LOSS OF TOURISM REVENUE DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) PROVIDING AERIAL ELEPHANT MONITORING SUPPORT FOR HEC-AFFECTED COMMUNITIES IN NLNP ADJACENT GAME MANAGEMENT AREAS; (2) PURCHASING RATIONS (MAIZE MEAL) FROM HEC-AFFECTED COMMUNITIES TO ESTABLISH LINKS BETWEEN RURAL FARMING LIVELIHOODS AND ELEPHANT CONSERVATION; AND (3) CONDUCTING HEC MITIGATION AND CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND OUTREACH WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING CONSTRUCTION OFELEPHANT-PROOF GRAIN STORES, PURCHASE OF MOTORCYCLES TO ENABLE SAFE DELIVERY OF COMMUNITY-LED MINI-CHANGE PROJECTS, AND REGIONAL EXCHANGE VISITS WITH OTHER HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE INITIATIVES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN NOUABALE-NDOKI NATIONAL PARK (NNNP) AND ADJACENT FORESTRY CONCESSIONS BY IMPROVING BIOLOGICAL AND HUMAN DISTURBANCE MONITORING AND BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF CENTRAL AFRICAN CONSERVATIONISTS. NORTHERN REPUBLIC OF CONGO, AS PART OF THE GREATER SANGHA-NDOKI REGION, IS ONE OF THE LAST REMAINING FOREST ELEPHANT STRONGHOLDS, WITH A POPULATION ESTIMATE OF MORE THAN 7,000 ELEPHANTS IN NNNP AND ITS PERIPHERY. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND SUPPORTING EVIDENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING BY CONSERVATION MANAGERS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) MAINTAINING A LANDSCAPE SCALE ACOUSTIC MONITORING SYSTEM AND ASSOCIATED DATA MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSES; (2) MONITORING OF ELEPHANT POPULATION DYNAMICS AND HABITAT USE, IN ADDITION TO ILLEGAL HUNTING WITH IMPROVED ACCURACY VIA CAMERA TRAPS; AND (3) ESTABLISHING A CENTER FOR ANALYSIS AND TRAINING AT NNNP TO SUPPORT CENTRAL AFRICAN BIOLOGISTS AND CONSERVATIONISTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN NSUMBU NATIONAL PARK AND SURROUNDING GAME MANAGEMENT AREAS BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING. NSUMBU NATIONAL PARK'S ELEPHANTS ARE GENETICALLY DISTINCT AND THE LAST ELEPHANTS FOUND ANYWHERE ALONG THE SHORES OF LAKE TANGANYIKA. THIS POPULATION OF APPROXIMATELY 150 INDIVIDUALS CONSTITUTES THE SURVIVING REMNANTS OF A MUCH WIDER HISTORIC ELEPHANT POPULATION THAT ONCE ROAMED THROUGHOUT THE REGION. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) PROVISIONING ADEQUATE SUPPLIES, INCLUDING VEHICLE PROCUREMENT, FUEL, RATIONS, AND COMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT FOR ANTI-POACHING PATROLS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN BENIN AND MOZAMBIQUE BY STRENGTHENING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A ROBUST IVORY STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. BENIN AND MOZAMBIQUE ARE HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 2,984 AND 10,884 ELEPHANTS RESPECTIVELY. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST AND SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND IVORY TRAFFICKING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) TRAINING GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS ON THE USE OF THE STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (SMS); (2) DEVELOPING STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES AND INVENTORY OF WILDLIFE PRODUCTS IN TARGET STOREROOMS; (3) CONDUCTING FOLLOW-UP TECHNICAL SUPPORT AND MENTORING TO ENSURE CONTINUED USE OF SMS IN 12 AFRICAN COUNTRIES; AND (4) CONDUCTING A PHYSICAL AUDIT OF AN IVORY STOCKPILE IN UGANDA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN CAMEROON BY STRENGTHENING THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL IVORY ACTION PLAN (NIAP) AND IMPROVING LAW ENFORCEMENT CAPACITY. CAMEROON IS HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 6,830 ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND IVORY TRAFFICKING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) SUPPORTING THE CAMEROONIAN GOVERNMENT IN MAKING THEIR NIAP COMMITTEE FUNCTIONAL, INCLUDING CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT; (2) DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING AN IVORY STOCKPILE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM; AND (3) BUILDING LAW ENFORCEMENT CAPACITY (INCLUDING THE MINISTRY OF FORESTS AND WILDLIFE) THROUGH TRAINING, INCLUDING THE MARKING, RECORDING AND MANAGEMENT OF SEIZED IVORY, LEGAL FRAMEWORKS, AND THE ELEPHANT TRADE INFORMATION SYSTEM (ETIS).
ADVANCING ELEPHANT CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE MIGRATORY ROUTES IN KENYA THROUGH STRENGTHENING COLLABORATION AND INCREASING LANDSCAPE CONNECTIVITY IN LAIKIPIA, KENYA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN LOWER ZAMBEZI NATIONAL PARK AND SURROUNDING GAME MANAGEMENT AREAS BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND IMPROVING PROTECTED AREA CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT. AS PART OF THE LUANGWA-ZAMBEZI VALLEY SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO ZAMBIA'S LARGEST POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS, WITH APPROXIMATELY 14,000 INDIVIDUALS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HABITAT LOSS, AND LOSS OF TOURISM REVENUE DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CONDUCTING GROUND AND AERIAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AND MONITORING PATROLS; (2) DEVELOPING A LONG-TERM TRAINING PROGRAM FOR ALL LAW ENFORCEMENT UNITS, IN ADDITION TO CONDUCTING REFRESHER TRAININGS FOR THE DETECTION AND TRACKING DOG UNIT; AND (3) PROVIDING CORE OPERATIONS SUPPORT FOR A FORWARD OPERATING BASE, OBSERVATION POINT, AND CONTROL CENTER.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN PENDJARI AND W NATIONAL PARKS BY STRENGTHENING BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, ELEPHANT PROTECTION, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE WAP COMPLEX FOREST ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD (A UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE), THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO WEST AFRICA'S LARGEST REMAINING ELEPHANT POPULATION, WITH APPROXIMATELY 4,178 INDIVIDUALS, OF WHICH MORE THAN HALF (APPROXIMATELY 2,272 ELEPHANTS) ARE LOCATED IN PENDJARI AND W NATIONAL PARKS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC), LIVESTOCK ENCROACHMENT, AND REGIONAL INSECURITY. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DEPLOYING ELEPHANT SATELLITE GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) COLLARS; (2) CONDUCTING RANGER-LED ELEPHANT MONITORING AND HEC INCIDENT RESPONSE PATROLS; (3) CONDUCTING A BIENNIAL LARGE MAMMAL AERIAL SURVEY; AND (4) ENGAGING WITH PASTORALISTS AND REDUCING LIVESTOCK ENCROACHMENT THROUGH AN ANNUAL LIVESTOCK VACCINATION CAMPAIGN AT THE PERIPHERY OF THE PROTECTED AREAS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION IN GARAMBA NATIONAL PARK (A UNESCO WORLD HERITAGE SITE) BY STRENGTHENING BIOLOGICAL MONITORING AND IMPROVING NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH CAPACITY. GARAMBA NATIONAL PARK IS HOME TO ONE OF THE LARGEST ELEPHANT POPULATIONS IN THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO (APPROXIMATELY 1,310 INDIVIDUALS). THESE ELEPHANTS ARE ALSO GENETICALLY UNIQUE, CONSTITUTING ONE OF THE FEW CONFIRMED HYBRID FOREST-SAVANNA ELEPHANT ZONES ON THE AFRICAN CONTINENT. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST, SAVANNA, AND FOREST-SAVANNA HYBRID ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND SUPPORTING EVIDENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING BY CONSERVATION MANAGERS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DEPLOYING AND MAINTAINING ELEPHANT SATELLITE GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM (GPS) COLLARS; (2) ANALYZING GPS COLLAR DATA AND BIENNIAL AERIAL SURVEY DATA TO INFORM PARK-WIDE OPERATIONS; (3) ESTABLISHING A BIODIVERSITY OBSERVATORY TO SUPPORT RESEARCH EFFORTS AND DEVELOP NATIONAL RESEARCH TALENT; AND (4) DEVELOPING A RESEARCH PAIRING PROGRAM WITH NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL GRADUATE STUDENTS.
PURSUING THE LONG-TERM PROTECTION OF ELEPHANT POPULATIONS AND OTHER WILDLIFE THREATENED SPECIES OF MBAM & DJEREM NATIONAL PARK LANDSCAPE, CAMEROON

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT ON COMMUNITY-OWNED LAND BETWEEN TSAVO, CHYULU HILLS, AND AMBOSELI NATIONAL PARKS, AND MAASAI MARA RESERVE BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, AND BUILDING A CONSTITUENCY FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION. AS PART OF THE KENYA RIFT VALLEY SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 12,814 ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC). SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) FACILITATING PEER-TO-PEER CONSERVATION LEARNING AND EXCHANGE AMONG COMMUNITY AND OPINION LEADERS; (2) CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONSERVATION-RELATED INVESTMENT IN UNDERFUNDED REGIONS, INCLUDING IDENTIFICATION OF POTENTIAL TOURISM SITES AND DEVELOPING PROPOSALS; (3) EXPANDING YOUTH CONSERVATION LEADERSHIP PROGRAMMING TO SCHOOLS LOCATED IN KEY ELEPHANT CORRIDORS; (4) PROVIDING OPERATIONAL SUPPORT AND COMMUNITY-BASED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT (CBNRM) TRAINING TO COMMUNITY RANGERS; AND (5) CONDUCTING HEC MITIGATION AND RAPID RESPONSE INTERVENTIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN THE IMENTI FOREST RESERVE BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. LOCATED WITHIN THE LAIKIPIA-SAMBURU ECOSYSTEM SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THE IMENTI RESERVE IS PART OF THE MOUNT KENYA PROTECTED AREA COMPLEX, WHICH IS HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 2,500 ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) AND POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DEPLOYING ANTI-POACHING PATROLS AND INSTALLING A RANGER OBSERVATION STATION; AND (2) CONDUCTING A COMMUNITY SURVEY TO DETERMINE THE MOST APPROPRIATE LOCATION FOR ELEPHANT-PROOF SHORT FENCING AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE SHORT FENCING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN SOUTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK BY STRENGTHENING ELEPHANT PROTECTION, BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE LUANGWA-ZAMBEZI VALLEY SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO ZAMBIA'S LARGEST POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS, WITH APPROXIMATELY 14,000 INDIVIDUALS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC), AND LOSS OF TOURISM REVENUE DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) PROVISIONING ADEQUATE FIELD SUPPLIES FOR YEAR-ROUND ANTI-POACHING PATROLS (E.G., FOOD RATIONS, VEHICLE FUEL, AND VEHICLE SPARE PARTS) AND PROCURING A SPEED BOAT AND ENGINE TO INCREASE RAINY SEASON PATROLS; (2) PROVIDING OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO THE CANINE DETECTION UNIT; AND (3) EXPANDING HEC RAPID RESPONSE UNIT EFFORTS, INCLUDING PATROL DEPLOYMENT, CONSTRUCTION OF ELEPHANT-PROOF ELECTRIC FENCING AND GRAIN STORES TO REDUCE CROP RAIDING, AND CONDUCTING HEC SENSITIZATION AND AWARENESS PROGRAMMING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A RANGE-WIDE ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT, WITH A FOCUS ON WEST AND CENTRAL AFRICA BY IMPROVING AFRICAN ELEPHANT GENETICS RESEARCH AND STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OF AFRICAN RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST AND SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF EXISTING GENETICS RESEARCH GAPS AND SUPPORTING EVIDENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING BY CONSERVATION MANAGERS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CONDUCTING GENOMIC SEQUENCING OF FOREST ELEPHANTS AND ANALYSIS OF WEST VERSUS CENTRAL AFRICAN FOREST ELEPHANTS TO DETERMINE THE DEGREE OF GENETIC DISTINCTIVENESS; (2) CONDUCTING GENOMIC ASSESSMENT OF ELEPHANTS AT THE EXTREMES OF THEIR RANGE TO DETERMINE GENETICALLY DISTINCT POPULATIONS WORTHY OF SEPARATE CONSERVATION PLANS; (3) TESTING A NOVEL ELEPHANT DUNG DNA COLLECTION METHOD WITH GENSAVER CARDS; (4) EXPANDING THE CAPABILITIES OF THE LOXODONTA LOCALIZER SOFTWARE TOOL; AND (5) PROVIDING CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT SUPPORT FOR AFRICAN ELEPHANT RANGE COUNTRY LABORATORIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A CONSERVATION EFFORT IN THE RUNGWA-KIZIGO-MUHESI GAME RESERVE COMPLEX, NYERERE NATIONAL PARK, UDZUNGWA MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK, AND THE KILOMBERO VALLEY, BY IMPROVING HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE AND ENHANCING LOCAL LIVELIHOODS. AS PART OF THE LARGER WESTERN TANZANIA REGION AND SELOUS-NIASSA REGION SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLDS, THIS LANDSCAPE IS HOME TO AN ESTIMATED 31,000 ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) AND POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) MONITORING AND MITIGATING HEC THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED DATA COLLECTION, BEEHIVE AND SOLAR-POWERED STROBE LIGHT FENCE CONSTRUCTION, AND IMPROVED CROP STORAGE; (2) TRAINING RANGERS TO DOCUMENT AND REPORT HEC INCIDENTS IN THE COMMUNITIES; (3) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND OUTREACH, INCLUDING SWAHILI-LANGUAGE HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE FILMS; AND (4) SUPPORTING A COMMUNITY LOAN AND INSURANCE PROGRAM AND ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS DEVELOPMENT.
OUR FOREST, OUR FUTURE: COMMUNITY-LED AFRICAN FOREST ELEPHANT (LOXODONTA CYCLOTIS) CONSERVATION IN THE BAS OGOOUE OF GABON
FURTHER STRENGTHEN THE PROTECTION OF ELEPHANTS AT YANKARI GAME RESERVE THROUGH ENHANCED LAW ENFORCEMENT ACTION AND MONITORING

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A RANGE-WIDE ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT BY CONTRIBUTING TO THE ONGOING WORK OF TRAFFIC INTERNATIONAL TO MANAGE THE ELEPHANT TRADE INFORMATION SYSTEM (ETIS) AS MANDATED BY THE CONVENTION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE IN ENDANGERED SPECIES OF WILD FAUNA AND FLORA (CITES) RESOLUTION CONF. 10.10 (REV. COP18) TRADE IN ELEPHANT SPECIMENS. THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN FOREST AND SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING AND TRAFFICKING OF IVORY AND OTHER ELEPHANT SPECIMENS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) MAINTAINING SUPPORT FOR MANAGEMENT OF THE ETIS, INCLUDING MAINTENANCE OF A WEBSITE IN THREE LANGUAGES; (2) CONDUCTING RELEVANT ANALYSES, INCLUDING FOR CITES COP19 IN PANAMA; AND (3) COORDINATING WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDING RESPONDING TO REQUESTS FROM CITES PARTIES AND THE CITES SECRETARIAT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN THE KAVANGO ZAMBEZI TRANSFRONTIER CONSERVATION AREA (KAZA TFCA) BY STRENGTHENING BIOLOGICAL MONITORING. THE KAZA TFCA SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD IS HOME TO APPROXIMATELY 192,500 ELEPHANTS, REPRESENTING MORE THAN HALF OF THE REMAINING SAVANNA ELEPHANTS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF EXISTING ELEPHANT POPULATION RESEARCH GAPS AND SUPPORTING EVIDENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING BY CONSERVATION MANAGERS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) PLANNING AND EXECUTING AN ACCURATE, SYNCHRONIZED AERIAL SURVEY OF ELEPHANTS IN THE KAZA TFCA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN RUAHA NATIONAL PARK AND SURROUNDING VILLAGES IN THE GREATER RUAHA-RUNGWA ECOSYSTEM BY IMPROVING HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE AND BUILDING A CONSTITUENCY FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION. AS PART OF THE LARGER WESTERN TANZANIA REGION SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO THE LARGEST POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS IN EAST AFRICA, WITH AN ESTIMATED 20,145 INDIVIDUALS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) AND POACHING. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) ORGANIZING PARK VISITATION AND ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL COMMUNITIES LIVING WITH ELEPHANTS; (2) CONSTRUCTING BEEHIVE BARRIER FENCES TO REDUCE ELEPHANT CROP RAIDING; (3) SYSTEMATICALLY MONITORING HEC EVENTS; AND (4) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMMING THROUGH PRIMARY SCHOOLS AND CONSERVATION FILM SCREENINGS WITH VILLAGES IDENTIFIED AS HEC HOTSPOTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AN ELEPHANT CONSERVATION EFFORT IN KATAVI NATIONAL PARK AND LWAFI GAME RESERVE BY IMPROVING TRANSBOUNDARY ELEPHANT MANAGEMENT BETWEEN TANZANIA AND ZAMBIA AND ENHANCING LOCAL PARTNER ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE LARGER WESTERN TANZANIA REGION SAVANNA ELEPHANT STRONGHOLD, THIS ECOSYSTEM IS HOME TO THE LARGEST POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS IN EAST AFRICA, WITH AN ESTIMATED 20,145 INDIVIDUALS. THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO CONSERVE AFRICAN SAVANNA ELEPHANTS AND THEIR HABITAT BY ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF POACHING, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION, AND HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC). SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY-BASED CAMERA TRAP MONITORING AND MAPPING OF TRANSBOUNDARY ELEPHANT MOVEMENTS; (2) ORGANIZING COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDER COORDINATION MEETINGS AND TECHNICAL AND COMMUNITY EXCHANGE VISITS BETWEEN TANZANIA AND ZAMBIA; AND (3) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY-BASED HEC MITIGATION PLANNING AND TRAINING.

THE MALI ELEPHANTS PROJECT, PHASE VII: DEVELOPING LONG-TERM STAKEHOLDER CAPACITY FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION IN MALI
IMPROVED SECURITY AND CONSERVATION OF ELEPHANTS IN TSAVO, KENYA
STRENGTHENING LONG-TERM PROTECTION OF ELEPHANTS IN SOUTHERN TANZANIA - 2
GENERATING LOCAL SUPPORT FOR ELEPHANT CONSERVATION NEAR RUAHA NATIONAL PARK, TANZANIA
INCREASING PROTECTION OF FOREST ELEPHANT POPULATIONS IN KEY PROTECTED AREAS AND INTERZONES IN THE NORTHERN TRIDOM LANDSCAPE, CAMEROON
THE TRANSBOUNDARY ELEPHANT RESEARCH PROGRAM WITHIN GREAT LIMPOPO TRANSFRONTIER PARK, SOUTH AFRICA
LAW ENFORCEMENT OPERATIONAL SUPPORT FOR ELEPHANT SECURITY IN THE NSUMBU-TANGANYIKA ECOSYSTEM
COMBATTING INCREASING PRESSURES ON THE THREATENED ELEPHANT POPULATION IN ZAMBIA'S SOUTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK, WITH IMPROVED TECHNOLOGY AND STRENGTHENING LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT CAPACITY
SUPPORTING THE GOVERNMENT OF COTE D'IVOIRE TO IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF THEIR IVORY STOCKPILES
IDENTIFYING THE LEVEL OF FUNDING NEEDED TO PROTECT ELEPHANT POPULATIONS ACROSS AFRICA AND OTHER KEY SPECIES
